doc.title: Cameco Corp. (CCJ): Production update a near-term hiccup, but long-term fundamentals intact - eidorate Buy
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Cameco Corp. CCJ Production update a near-term hiccup but long-term fundamentals intact reiterate BuyCameco Corp. CCJ Pr_2025-08-29

passages.text: On 8/28, CCJ provided a production update, reducing forecasted 2025 production for McArthur River by \(\sim 3\mathrm{mn} - 4\mathrm{mn}\) lbs (now 14mn- 15mn lbs). The company did highlight that there is potential to get an additional 1mn lbs out of Cigar Lake to make up some of the shortfall but is not base- casing this currently. While a near- term execution hiccup, we note risks to McArthur River was previously highlighted this year given development of new mining sites and impact from freezing conditions earlier in the year, and we view the production cut to be a positive to pricing in the near- to- medium term, somewhat offsetting the impact from lower production. Longer- term, given our view on the current U3O8 supply/demand dynamic which we expect will lead to higher pricing over the next several years, we see this production reduction as another positive in this regards supporting the structural deficit thesis. We reiterate our Buy rating on CCJ and highlight our takeaways within.

2025 production forecast revised downward. CCJ issued a production update to the 2025 production plan for its mining assets where CCJ is now revising down guidance slightly. We note that earlier in the year CCJ highlighted risks to McArthur River and Key Lake mill's production schedule which had the potential to impact the timing of production. In the current production update, CCJ notes that the company is unable to completely offset the delays relating to development and slower than expected ground freezing in the first half of 2025. As a result, CCJ is lowering its expectation of extracted lbs. from McArthur River for 2025. Production from McArthur River/Key Lake mill is now anticipated to be 14mn- 15mn lbs. (vs. 18mn lbs. prior) on a \(100\%\) basis (implying CCJ's share is now 9.8mn- 10.5mn lbs). At the mid- point, the cut to McArthur river represents a reduction of 3.5mn lbs. or roughly a \((19\%)\) reduction in production out of the mine. We do highlight that CCJ notes that Cigar Lake production has been strong this year and there remains a potential to increase production out of this asset and offset 1mn lbs. of the 3mn- 4mn lb. shortfall from McArthur River (on \(100\%\) basis). We note that while this impacts current year production, we view this as an incremental positive for long- term fundamentals, supporting a structural deficit and higher pricing framework for U3O8 broadly.

Global supply and demand implications. We note that the reduction of 3mn- 4mn lbs. of U3O8 represents a reduction of roughly \(1.8\% - 2.4\%\) of global uranium production for 2025. With so much focus and debate recently on supply and demand implications, we view investors and utilities will take note of one of the world's

largest and most consistent producers of uranium experiencing a setback. We view this speaks to the broader industry and highlights how challenging uranium mining is and how unpredictable bringing on additional supply could be.

Pricing implications. While this production is not lost and merely just delayed, we view that this news should be a tailwind to spot pricing in the near- term. We note that U308 spot prices have been increasing since the end of July, as spot has increased from \(\) 71/1b\(to\) \ \(75/1b\) over the past 4 weeks and this production cut news could serve as another catalyst to move prices higher, in our view. We highlight that this production cut comes the week before the World Nuclear Symposium which takes place on September 3- 5, a closely- followed industry event at which we believe any new data points on demand or new RFPs could be a catalyst for sparking more utility buying in the term- market and lead to higher- term pricing which has remained at - \(\) 80/1b\(over the past 12 - months. We also note that recently we have seen an increase in long - term contracting this month with >12mn lbs. contracted in August, however, term contracting volumes still remain (36%) below historic YTD volumes as of August 25th.
Estimate changes. Our 2025E- 2027E adj. EBITDA estimates move \((4\%) / 0\% /0\%\) to \(\) 1.91bn/C\(\) 2.25bn/C\(\) 2.57bn\(as we adjust this year's production estimate.

CCJ/CCO.TO. Our 12- month price targets remain unchanged at \(\) 95/C\$ 131 and is based on a sum of the parts valuation based on a 20X EV/EBITDA multiple on our Q5- Q8 EBITDA estimates for uranium, 25X EV/EBITDA multiple on Q5- Q8 EBITDA estimates for fuel services, and 30X EV/EBITDA multiple on Q5- Q8 estimates for Westinghouse.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Quantum is Goldman Sachs' proprietary database providing access to detailed financial statement histories, forecasts and ratios. It can be used for in- depth analysis of a single company, or to make comparisons between companies in different sectors and markets.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

Not Rated (NR). Early- Stage Biotech (ES).
